Description: Rim and upper body sherd of Corinthian Conventionalizing pottery convex-walled pyxis; interior glazed black at rim, reserved below; exterior: streaky black rim, raised fillet at junction with shoulder with black band below; on shoulder painted decoration consisting of parts of two horizontal palmettes (left-hand palmette lies with top to right; right-hand palmette is circumscribed and lies with top to left).
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The sherd belongs to the same vase as Oxford, Ashmolean Museum, Unnumbered 41 and Unnumbered 42. For the shape and style, see Payne (1931), p. 331 for a pyxis with convex sides and cylindrical handles (Cat. Nos. 1493-7 and 1553). For parallels regarding the palmette decoration, see nos 1047a and 1065 in A.G. Newhall Stillwell and J.L. Benson, Corinth: The Potter's Quarter: Vol. XV, Part III (1984).
Bibliographic references: Payne 1931 / Necrocorinthia. A study of corinthian art in the archaic period (Catalogue no. 1491)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 72, pl. VI, no. 23.)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.327) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
